english: dirt, anything dirty - usually in child’s talk.

example: Nagimas ti taro nga kanen. (The taro is delicious to eat.)

english: to drink directly from a fountain or faucet with the lips touching the source of the water.
example: Saan mo nga ab- aban dayta gripo ta narugit. (Don’t drink from the faucet with your lips for it is dirty.)
Ababa ti dila na. (His tongue is short.)

english: shallow, not deep; superficial not profound.
example: Narabaw ti karayan, a mangipalubos kadakami a nalaka a bumallasiw iti sabali a bangir. (The river was shallow, allowing us to easily wade across to the other side.)
Inawitna ti nadagsen a bag iti abagana. (He carried the heavy bag on his shoulder.)

Ti angin nga abagatan ti nangyeg iti nabara nga angin iti ili iti igid ti baybay, a mangipasimudaag iti panangrugi ti makaay-ayo nga aldaw ti kalgaw. (The south wind brought a warm breeze to the coastal town, signaling the beginning of a pleasant summer day.)
Planok ti agbiahe nga agpa-abagatan para iti bakasion iti aplaya inton sumaruno a bulan. (I plan to travel south for a beach vacation next month.)

english: to defeat or win over (someone) (in gambling, a contest, etc.).
example: Siak ti immabak kanyana. (It was I who defeated him.)

Masansan a mausar ti abaka ti Manila, a pagaammo gapu iti kinaandur ken kinatibkerna iti panagaramid iti tali ken tali. (Manila hemp, known for its durability and strength, is often used in making ropes and twines.)

english: a type of brown, burrowing June beetle or June bug.
example: Nakitak ti maysa a June beetle nga agkarayam iti beranda bayat ti nabara a malem ti kalgaw. (I spotted a June beetle crawling on the porch during the warm summer evening.)

english: relationship between parents of a married couple.
example: Abalayan ko ni Ana. (Ana is the mother of my child’s spouse.)

english: to play with as with a toy; to trifle with.
example: Saan mo nga abalbalayen dayta. (Don’t play with that.)

english: a kind of white larva that lives in the earth and kill plants by knawing at their roots.
example: Nasaknap ti hardin kadagiti abalen, a nakaigapuan ti pannakaseknan dagiti mannalon. (The garden was infested with white larvae, causing concern among the farmers.)
Ag-paypay ti bagi ni Jane babaen ti abaniko bayat ti nabara a malem. (Jane fan herself with a hand fan during the warm afternoon.)
Masapul a bayadantayo ti binulan nga abang ti apartmenttayo inton ngudo ti lawas. (We need to pay the monthly rent for our apartment by the end of the week.)
Mapan ka idiay abay ni manong mo. (Go to the side of your older brother.)

english: to let the water or liquid (of what one is cooking) evaporate, to allow to dry up by steaming.
example: Saan mo nga abbatan dayta lutlutoem. (Don’t let the liquid of what you are cooking evaporate.)
Inusarna ti namaris a kubrekama a mangabbong iti bagina bayat ti nalamiis a rabii. (She used a colorful blanket to cover herself during the chilly night.)

english: textile, specifically cloth woven in a native loom.
example: Siaannad a sinukimatna ti nabiag a abel sakbay nga inkeddengna nga usaren dayta para iti baro a proyektona a panagdait. (She carefully examined the vibrant textile before deciding to use it for her new sewing project.)
Sinukimat ti agtutubo nga abenturero ti napuskol a kabakiran tapno agsapul kadagiti nailemmeng a gameng. (The young adventurer explored the dense forest in search of hidden treasures.)

english: a kind of fish about size and shape of a sardine whose meat is esteemed.
example: Napartak ti pangngaldawko ket nagaramidak iti simple a sandwich nga addaan aber na. (I had a quick lunch and made a simple sandwich with sardines like meat.)

english: to mock, insult, affront, villify; to belittle.
example: Ab-abien da ta napanglaw. (They are belittling him because he is poor.)

english: to throw a wrap over one's shoulder, to wrap oneself around the shoulder.
example: Iyabiday mo daytoy ta nalam-ek. (Wrap this around your shoulder for it is cold.)

english: to have adulterous relations with someone; to commit adultery.
example: Saan ka nga makiabig. (Don’t commit adultery.)

english: the relationship between two persons whose spouses are brothers or sisters.
example: Ti asawa ni adingko ket katugangak. (My sister's husband is my brother-in-law.)

english: to whip in a slashing manner.
example: Inikkanna ti alpombra iti nasayaat a ablat tapno maikkat ti rugit ken mapabiag manen. (She gave the lazy carpet a good whip to remove the dust and bring it back to life.)

english: to weave in a native loom
example: Nasursurona ti agablen iti napintas a basket manipud ken ni lolana. (She learned how to weave a beautiful basket from her grandmother.)
Nangipaay ti abogado iti legal a balakad kadagiti kliyentena bayat ti proseso ti diborsio. (The lawyer provided legal advice to her clients during the divorce proceedings.)

Tinagiragsakna ti naimas nga abokado toast para iti pammigat. (She enjoyed a delicious avocado toast for breakfast.)

english: a kind of large, red, stinging ant whose eggs are edible.
example: Liniklikak ti dadakkel a aboos nga agkarayam iti lamisaan a pagpiknikan. (I avoided the large red ant crawling on the picnic table.)
Abrawem man daydiay tarong ken parya. (Cook the eggplant and bitter melon into a vegetable dish please.)

Inusarna ti abrilata manglukat iti lata ti beans para iti pangrabii. (She used a can-opener to open the can of beans for dinner.)
In-abrisieten na isuna ti panagsalada iti sirok ti lawag ti bulan. (He held her in the waist as they danced under the moonlight.)
Abrotem ti abak mo idi kalman. (Recover your losses yesterday.)
Abugem dayta aso. (Drive away that dog.)

english: fence enclosing the space under a house built on stilts.
example: Adda abulog na nga kawayan diay balay mi. (The space under our house is fenced with bamboo.)

english: to acquiesce, consent to, agree with, approve.
example: Saan mo nga abuloyan ta kaykayat na. (Don’t acquiesce to what he wants.)

english: a small hut; a small hut-like structure used in religious processions as a repository for the Blessed Sacrament.
example: Bayat ti piesta, awit dagiti deboto dagiti daton iti abung-abung kas paset ti narelihiosuan a prosesyon. (During the festival, devotees carried offerings in a small hut as part of the religious procession.)

english: to cover one’s head or eyes (with a handkerchief, a bandana, etc.).
example: Agabungot ka ket agar-arbis. (Cover your head (with a bandana or any piece of cloth) for it is drizzling.)

english: a female who gave birth to twins, triplets, etc. of the same-sex.
example: Ti aburoy ket nangipasngay iti singin a lalaki, idi rabii idiay ospital. (The female gave birth to a boy twins, last night at the hospital.)

english: while, whereas, although, in spite of the fact that.
example: Abus ta isu ti nakabasol, isu pay ti nagunget. (In spite of the fact that it was he who sinned, it was also he who got angry.)

Intultuloy dagiti ubbing ti agabuso kadagiti dadakkelda para iti sorbetes agingga a nagbabawida kamaudiananna ket gimmatangda iti sumagmamano. (The children continued to pester their parents for ice cream until they finally relented and bought some.)

english: to reach, arrive in; hole, opening
example: Immabutak idiay Manila. (I reached Manila.)

Nakita dagiti agdaldaliasat ti maysa a abuyo iti bantay nga aglukluksaw iti desdes bayat ti panagdaliasatda iti kabakiran. (The hikers spotted a mountain chicken hopping along the trail during their trek through the forest.)

english: the existence or presence of someone or something.
example: Adda tao idiay balay. (There is someone in the house.)

english: to study one's lesson or course
example: Agadal kanga naimbag tapno makaruar ka. (You study your lesson well so that you will pass it.)
Agnanaed ti ikan iti adalem a taaw. (The fish lives deep in the ocean.)
Umadanin ti paskua. (Christmas is approaching.)

english: bad or unpleasant taste, as the aftertaste of oysters or mangoes.
example: Ngem ti adat na, awan ti ladawan nga irapit maipanggep iti salaysay. (The bad taste lies in that there is no picture enclosed pertaining to the story.)
Umadawak man. (May I borrow fire (from you).)

english: far, distant, remote (in space or probability); far from (someone or something)
example: Adayo ti Amerika ditoy Pilipinas. (America (or the U.S.A.) is far from the Philippines,)

english: to put weight on so as to press (it) down, to lie on.
example: Saan mo nga addagan dagita kallaba nga lupot. (Don’t lie on those newly-washed clothes.)

english: var. of adani; to approach, come near.
example: Umadanin ti paskua. (Christmas is approaching.)

english: to move the legs so as to walk; to make a step; to pace, walk.
example: Damo na pay la ti agaddang. (He is still beginning to walk.)

english: there yonder (it) is, there yonder (they) are.
example: Sadiay, adda, ti daan nga oak tree a dati nga ay-ayamenmi iti sirokna. (Yonder, there it is, the old oak tree we used to play under.)

english: there near you (it) is, there near you (they) are.
example: Addayta, iti asidegmo, ti libro a sapsapulem. (There it is, near you, the book you've been looking for.)

english: younger brother or sister; anyone, especially a relative, younger than oneself.
example: Agay-ayam ti adi'k kadagiti ay-ayam a kotse. (My younger brother plays with toy cars.)

english: var. of sadino; where, to whom.
